page.title: 04PLACE OF WORSHIP-BLEWBURY
page.content: THE SAXON CHURCH REFERRED TO IN DOMESDAY BOOK WOULD HAVE BEEN A SMALL NAVE WITH A VERY SMALL SANCTUARY AT THE EAST END.VERY SOON AFTER THIS,THE WHOLE STRUCTURE WAS REBUILT BY THE NORMANS TO A SIMILAR AN BUT OF LARGER DIMENSIONS. TOWARDS THE END OF THE 12TH CENTURY THE SMALL SANCTUARY WAS GREATLY ENLARGED BY THE ADDITION OF A FINELY VAULTED CHANCEL;TRANSEPTS WERE ERECTED AND A CENTRAL TOWER ROSE FROM THE CROSSING PRESENTING THE POPULAR CRUCIFORM PLAN. FOUR BELLS WERE HUNG AT SOME TIME. IN THE NEXT CENTURY THE SOUTH AISLE WAS ADDED AS FAR AS THE TRANSEPT WHILE THE NORTH AISLE AND THE LADY CHAPEL TO THE SOUTH OF THE CHANCEL WERE ADDED IN THE 14TH CENTURY.IN THE 14TH OR 15TH CENTURY WAS ERECTED THE ROOD LOFT AND SCREEN ACROSS THE EAST END OF THE NAVE, THE STAIRS TO THE LOFT BEING CUT OUT OF THE THICK WALL OF THE NORMAN NAVE.
